grounding: The past half-century has seen major shifts in inflation expectations, how inflation comoves with the business cycle, and how stocks comove with Treasury bonds. Against this backdrop, we review the economic channels and empirical evidence on how inflation is priced in financial markets. Not all inflation episodes are created equal. Using a New Keynesian model, we show how “good” inflation can be linked to demand shocks and “bad” inflation to cost-push shocks driving the economy. We then discuss asset pricing implications of “good” and “bad” inflation. We conclude by providing an outlook for inflation risk premia in the world of newly rising inflation.
generated_text: This study examines the complex relationship between inflation and asset returns across various economic environments. We analyze historical data to investigate how inflation impacts risk premia and bond return predictability. Our findings reveal that during periods of stagflation, traditional asset allocation strategies may underperform, necessitating a reevaluation of investment approaches. We also explore the role of monetary policy in shaping inflation expectations and its subsequent effects on asset prices. Our results suggest that incorporating inflation dynamics into investment decision-making processes can potentially enhance portfolio performance and risk management strategies. This research contributes to the ongoing debate on the optimal asset allocation in inflationary environments and provides insights for both academics and practitioners.
